<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will determine the diameter of a marble by two methods and calculate the density of the material from which the marble is made.

<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 120, 203, 135]]<|/det|>
# Method 1

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 149, 576, 168]]<|/det|>
Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[163, 175, 833, 301]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[331, 317, 665, 336]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.1</label> <label>(Apparatus viewed from above)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 348, 144, 367]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 348, 180, 367]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 348, 920, 383]]<|/det|>
Place the metre ruler on the bench with its scale facing upwards. Arrange one of the wooden blocks and the five marbles as shown in Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 380, 542, 397]]<|/det|>
Measure the length \(D\) for the five marbles.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[549, 410, 920, 428]]<|/det|>
<form>D = .................................................... $cm$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 441, 787, 460]]<|/det|>
Using your value of \(D\), calculate the average diameter \(d_{1}\) of **one** marble.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 502, 920, 521]]<|/det|>
<form>d_{1} = ............................................................ $cm$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 520, 920, 537]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 549, 181, 568]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 549, 920, 583]]<|/det|>
Suggest why it is more accurate, when using a ruler, to measure \(D\) for **five** marbles rather than measure the diameter of a single marble.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 658, 920, 677]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 203, 88]]<|/det|>
## Method 2  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 148, 120]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 102, 920, 134]]<|/det|>
Describe how the two wooden blocks and one of the marbles can be used to determine an accurate value for the diameter of a marble.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 133, 608, 151]]<|/det|>
Draw a diagram to show your suggested arrangement.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 147, 920, 181]]<|/det|>
Describe clearly how you ensure that your value for the diameter of a marble is as accurate as possible.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 395, 692, 413]]<|/det|>
Use your arrangement to measure the diameter \(d_{2}\) of the marble.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 426, 920, 445]]<|/det|>
<form>\(d_{2} =\) ............................................................ $cm$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 443, 920, 460]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 473, 144, 492]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 473, 180, 492]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 473, 920, 507]]<|/det|>
Use the top-pan balance as shown in Fig. 1.2 to measure the mass \(m\) of one of the marbles.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[245, 515, 751, 635]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 648, 534, 667]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[547, 710, 920, 728]]<|/det|>
<form>m = ....................................................... $g$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[893, 710, 920, 728]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 72, 181, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 71, 720, 89]]<|/det|>
Pour approximately \(25 \text{cm}^3\) of water into the measuring cylinder.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 102, 742, 120]]<|/det|>
Record the reading \(V_{1}\) of the water level in the measuring cylinder.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 133, 920, 151]]<|/det|>
<form>V_1 = .................................................... $cm^3$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 164, 920, 198]]<|/det|>
Carefully place the 5 marbles into the water in the measuring cylinder as shown in Fig. 1.3.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[272, 205, 761, 490]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 505, 534, 523]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 536, 781, 555]]<|/det|>
Record the new reading \(V_{2}\) of the water level in the measuring cylinder.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[546, 567, 920, 585]]<|/det|>
<form>V_2 = .................................................... $cm^3$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 597, 824, 616]]<|/det|>
Calculate a value for the average volume \(V\) of **one** marble. Use the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 618, 556, 650]]<|/det|>
\[V = \frac{V_2 - V_1}{5}.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 675, 920, 693]]<|/det|>
<form>V = .................................................... $cm^3$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 692, 920, 710]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 723, 180, 741]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 723, 920, 755]]<|/det|>
Draw, on Fig. 1.3, an arrow showing the correct line of sight for reading the water level in the measuring cylinder.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 737, 920, 756]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 769, 181, 787]]<|/det|>
<label>(iv)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 769, 920, 802]]<|/det|>
Calculate a value for the density \(\rho\) of the material from which the marble is made. Use your values of \(m\) from (c)(i), \(V\) from (c)(ii) and the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 807, 534, 836]]<|/det|>
\[\rho = \frac{m}{V}.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 875, 920, 894]]<|/det|>
<form>\(\rho =\) .................................................... $g / cm^3$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 875, 920, 894]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 96, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 910, 91]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will investigate the cooling of hot water from different initial temperatures.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 576, 122]]<|/det|>
Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[129, 128, 870, 317]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 331, 532, 350]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 363, 146, 381]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 363, 279, 380]]<|/det|>
Experiment A

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 378, 500, 396]]<|/det|>
Pour \(100 \text{cm}^3\) of hot water into the beaker.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 393, 564, 412]]<|/det|>
Place the thermometer in the water in the beaker.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 424, 920, 458]]<|/det|>
In the first row of Table 2.1, record the temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{A}}\) of the water at time \(t = 0 \text{s}\) and immediately start the stop-watch.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 471, 920, 505]]<|/det|>
Record, in Table 2.1, the temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{A}}\) of the water at times \(t = 30 \text{s}\), \(t = 60 \text{s}\), \(t = 90 \text{s}\), \(t = 120 \text{s}\), \(t = 150 \text{s}\) and \(t = 180 \text{s}\). [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 518, 308, 536]]<|/det|>
Empty the beaker.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 549, 146, 567]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 549, 279, 567]]<|/det|>
Experiment B

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 564, 504, 582]]<|/det|>
Pour \(100 \text{cm}^3\) of hot water into the beaker.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 579, 564, 597]]<|/det|>
Place the thermometer in the water in the beaker.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 610, 920, 644]]<|/det|>
Wait until the temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{B}}\) of the water has reached the same value as the temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{A}}\) at \(t = 90 \text{s}\) in Experiment A.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 656, 920, 689]]<|/det|>
In the first row of Table 2.1, record this temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{B}}\) of the water at time \(t = 0 \text{s}\) and immediately start the stop-watch.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 920, 104]]<|/det|> Record, in Table 2.1, the temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{B}}\) of the water at times \(t = 30 \mathrm{~s}\), \(t = 60 \mathrm{~s}\), \(t = 90 \mathrm{~s}\), \(t = 120 \mathrm{~s}\), \(t = 150 \mathrm{~s}\) and \(t = 180 \mathrm{~s}\). <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[455, 119, 541, 134]]<|/det|> Table 2.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[336, 144, 662, 345]]<|/det|>
\(t/\mathrm {s}\)\(\theta _{\mathrm {A}}/^{\circ }\mathrm {C}\)\(\theta _{\mathrm {B}}/^{\circ }\mathrm {C}\)
0
30
60
90
120
150
180
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 345, 920, 364]]<|/det|> [3] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 378, 144, 396]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 377, 920, 410]]<|/det|> Write a conclusion stating how the temperature at \(t = 0s\) affects the rate of cooling of the water. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 408, 655, 427]]<|/det|> Justify your answer by reference to values from your results. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 534, 920, 551]]<|/det|> [2] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 564, 146, 583]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[161, 564, 188, 583]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 564, 836, 583]]<|/det|> Calculate the average cooling rate \(x_{1}\) during the second half of Experiment A. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 579, 615, 598]]<|/det|> Use your readings from Table 2.1 and the equation <|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[428, 602, 571, 633]]<|/det|> \[x_{1} = \frac{\theta_{\mathrm{A}90} - \theta_{\mathrm{A}180}}{T}\] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 641, 920, 675]]<|/det|> where \(T = 90 \mathrm{~s}\) and \(\theta_{\mathrm{A}90}\) and \(\theta_{\mathrm{A}180}\) are the temperatures at \(t = 90 \mathrm{~s}\) and \(t = 180 \mathrm{~s}\) in Experiment A. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 672, 500, 689]]<|/det|> Include the unit for the cooling rate. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 733, 920, 752]]<|/det|>
\(x_{1} =\) ........................................................ <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 765, 181, 784]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 765, 809, 784]]<|/det|> Calculate the average cooling rate \(x_{2}\) during the first half of Experiment B. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 780, 603, 797]]<|/det|> Use the readings from Table 2.1 and the equation <|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[435, 803, 562, 833]]<|/det|> \[x_{2} = \frac{\theta_{\mathrm{B}0} - \theta_{\mathrm{B}90}}{T}\] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 842, 920, 875]]<|/det|> where \(T = 90 \mathrm{~s}\) and \(\theta_{\mathrm{B}0}\) and \(\theta_{\mathrm{B}90}\) are the temperatures at \(t = 0 \mathrm{~s}\) and \(t = 90 \mathrm{~s}\) in Experiment B. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 919, 920, 937]]<|/det|> \(x_{2} =\) ........................................................ <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 919, 920, 937]]<|/det|> [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 92, 90]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 839, 106]]<|/det|> In this experiment, you will determine the resistance per unit length of a resistance wire. The circuit has been set up for you. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 117, 576, 137]]<|/det|> Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 3.1. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 144, 808, 365]]<|/det|> <|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 380, 532, 399]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 411, 144, 429]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 411, 744, 430]]<|/det|> Connect the crocodile clip to a length \(l = 20.0 \text{cm}\) of the resistance wire. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 443, 299, 460]]<|/det|> Close the switch. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 473, 920, 508]]<|/det|> Measure and record in Table 3.1, the value of potential difference (p.d.) \(V\) and current \(I\) for the resistance wire. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 520, 920, 554]]<|/det|> Connect the crocodile clip to lengths \(l = 40.0 \text{cm}\) , \(l = 60.0 \text{cm}\) , \(l = 80.0 \text{cm}\) and \(l = 100.0 \text{cm}\) of the resistance wire. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 551, 920, 585]]<|/det|> For each length \(l,\) measure and record in Table 3.1, the value of potential difference \(V\) and current \(I\) for the resistance wire. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 598, 297, 616]]<|/det|> Open the switch. <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 628, 541, 645]]<|/det|> Table 3.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[285, 655, 712, 807]]<|/det|>
l/ cmV/VI/AR/Ω
20.0
40.0
60.0
80.0
100.0
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 808, 920, 826]]<|/det|> [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 72, 918, 106]]<|/det|>
For each length \(l\) calculate and record in Table 3.1, the resistance \(R\) of the resistance wire. Use your values of \(V\) and \(I\) from Table 3.1 and the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 107, 532, 139]]<|/det|>
\[R = \frac{V}{I}.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 134, 920, 153]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 165, 144, 183]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 165, 569, 183]]<|/det|>
Plot a graph of \(R / \Omega\) (y-axis) against \(l / \text{cm}\) (x-axis).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 180, 403, 198]]<|/det|>
Draw a straight line of best fit.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[227, 207, 767, 555]]<|/det|>

<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 584, 920, 617]]<|/det|>
Determine the gradient \(G\) of the graph. Show clearly on the graph how you obtained the necessary information.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 644, 920, 662]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 676, 181, 694]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<label>(e)</label>

<mark>[Turn over

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 94, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 591, 89]]<|/det|>
A student investigates the motion of a ball through the air.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 103, 918, 135]]<|/det|>
Plan an experiment which will enable him to investigate how the range of the ball depends on the angle at which it is launched.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 135, 918, 167]]<|/det|>
The range is the horizontal distance that the ball travels after leaving the end of the channel shown in Fig. 4.1 and before hitting the ground.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 180, 470, 197]]<|/det|>
You are **not** required to do the experiment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 211, 398, 228]]<|/det|>
The apparatus available includes:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 243, 136, 259]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 242, 789, 259]]<|/det|>
a flexible channel, as shown in Fig. 4.1, which can be bent at different angles

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 259, 136, 275]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 259, 623, 275]]<|/det|>
a selection of balls, each of different diameter and mass.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 289, 324, 306]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 320, 460, 337]]<|/det|>
· list any additional apparatus needed

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 336, 138, 353]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

· state the key variables to keep constant

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 368, 920, 400]]<|/det|>
